Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Highly Nonlinear Transducer Arrays for Structural Health Monitoring

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This propoject will investigate the fundamental properties and applications of novel arrays of nonlinear actuators for the nondestructive evaluation (NDE) and structural health monitoring (SHM) of civil structures and materials. The investigators will also explore the ability to use the nonlinear actuators for focusing and harvesting elastic energy, and for imaging bulk materials. The arrays of nonlinear actuators included in this study can generate highly nonlinear solitary waves (HNSWs), which are compact non-dispersive stress waves with a finite spatial dimension. The spatial dimension of these pulses is independent of the wave amplitude and dependent only on the nonlinear material's geometry. HNSWs hold promise to improve current NDE/SHM devices because of their ability to support non-oscillatory, high amplitude signals that rely exclusively on mechanical excitations.

On a fundamental level, the investigators aim at understanding the behavior of arrays of highly nonlinear actuators adjacent to different neighboring solid media. In particular, they will: (i) study the ability to focus nonlinear waves as a function of the properties of the adjacent media, (ii) design and implement methods to improve transmission of the signal across the interface between the actuators and the adjacent media; (iii) determine the limitations of signal power and the degradation of performance due to failure of the highly nonlinear actuators. From a purely applied perspective, the project will be devoted to the application of HNSWs for the NDE/SHM of structural materials.

Besides the impact to the nonlinear dynamics scientific community, the proposed research will have strategic importance to a broad range of engineering applications. The NDE/SHM component of this research enables to increase the safety of existing civil and aerospace structures. The ability to harvest focused elastic energy has the potential to create new, sustainable means to power small electronic devices and sensors. This research outcomes will enable the development of novel transducers arrays for acoustic imaging, the successful outcome of our research could impact the biomedical imaging community.

Some of the research outcomes and experiments will be integrated into the investigators' teaching portfolio and into outreach activities. This research will provide multidisciplinary training for all participating students. As the submission of at least one patent application is forecast, potential marketing opportunities will be explored. Finally, the research results will be broadly disseminated through the submission of journal articles and through the presentation at conferences of international audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported by this NSF award focused on the fundamental study of nonlinear systems to control the propagation of stress waves (or elastic waves) through solid media. The ability to tailor how waves travel through mechanical systems and materials is very important in engineering applications, for example, for the control of noise and vibrations, for the non destructive testing and evaluation of materials and for the quality control of mechanical components. In this project, we focused on the study of "discrete systems", which are systems consisting of a small number of components (like layers, plates or granular particles) as passive materials that can control how waves travel, reflect or remain trapped in selected spatial regions. We combined computational and theoretical approaches to design specialized materials and system that can support the propagation of compact pulses (i.e., solitary waves) and validated our approaches with table-top experiments. We selected the use of "bistable" componenets for our systems, which are components that can switch between two or more stable positions (or phases), because they can be accurately designed to respond to selected external threats or excitations. We found that in discrete systems composed by several bistable elements, waves can only travel in one direction, as the elements can only switch from a phase that has higher energy to a phase having lower energy. This finding is very important for engineering applications that require control in the transmission of impacts, or need to reduce vibrations or noise. We also observed that the energy transported by the waves in these systems exhibits a linear scaling to its velocity. This is an important fundamental finding that can serve as a design principle for specific industrial or applied problems. We have described these findings in three journal publications [1,2,3]. 

More broadly, this study focused on a new approach to design "metamaterials", which are engineered materials that have properties not found in nature, usually derived from the geometry of their structure. Current research in the area of metamaterials is mostly focused on linear systems (which are easier to build and analyse). Applications of metamaterials include acoustic lenses (used in biomedical imaging), sound isolators and acoustic sensing, as well as acoustic cloaks (for example to be used for sonar invisibility). However, usign the "linear" approximation in the design of metamaterials is limiting. We chose to use nonlinearities (like those arising from contacts and/or bistable systems), to allow new physical phenomena to emerge, like uni-directional wave propagation, passive actuation and active control of vibration. We experimentally demonstrate these phenomena through proof-of-concept experiments.

At a more fundamental level, the findings of our work also provide basic understanding of the strongly nonlinear dynamics of all physical systems exhibiting phase transitions. A phase transition is a dynamical process where a system having multiple equilibrium phases switchesfrom one equilibrium phase to another. Phase transitions occur in a myriad of physical (for e.g., domainswitching in ferroelectric ceramics, and dynamics of CNT foams), chemical (for e.g., intercalation of Li inelectrodes of Li-ion batteries, and chemical surface adsorption), and biological systems (for e.g., protonmobility in hydrogen-bonded chains, and rotation of DNA bases). We find that the complex dynamics of this process depends upon the external driving force and the relative energy levels of the two phases.

The findings of this project build a fundation for further studies of more complex and higher dimensional systems, but could also be directly exploted in engineering applications, which require specific wave propagation properties.
